message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Chatbots for language learning—Are they really useful? A systematic review of chatbot‐supported language learning
Paper Abstract: Abstract Background The use of chatbots as learning assistants is receiving increasing attention in language learning due to their ability to converse with students using natural language. Previous reviews mainly focused on only one or two narrow aspects of chatbot use in language learning. This review goes beyond merely reporting the specific types of chatbot employed in past empirical studies and examines the usefulness of chatbots in language learning, including first language learning, second language learning, and foreign language learning. Aims The primary purpose of this review is to discover the possible technological, pedagogical, and social affordances enabled by chatbots in language learning. Materials & Methods We conducted a systematic search and identifies 25 empirical studies that examined the use of chatbots in language learning. We used the inductive grounded approach to identify the technological and pedagogical affordances, and the challenges of using chatbots for students’ language learning. We used Garrison's social presence framework to analyze the social affordances of using chatbots in language learning Results Our findings revealed three technological affordances: timeliness, ease of use, and personalization; and five pedagogical uses: as interlocutors, as simulations, for transmission, as helplines, and for recommendations. Chatbots appeared to encourage students’ social presence by affective, open, and coherent communication. Several challenges in using chatbots were identified: technological limitations, the novelty effect, and cognitive load. Discussion and Conclusion A set of rudimentary design principles for chatbots are proposed for meaningfully implementing educational chatbots in language learning, and detailed suggestions for future research are presented.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Natural language processing." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Main Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s, when Alan Turing published an article titled "Computing Machinery and Intelligence" which proposed the Turing test as a criterion of intelligence, including a task that involves the automated interpretation and generation of natural language.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

## Recent Advances

Novel algorithms, availability of larger datasets and higher processing power made possible training of larger language models. The attention mechanism was introduced in 2014, which laid the foundations for the Transformer architecture introduced in 2017.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Links: [{"title":"Second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Theories of second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theories_of_second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Generative second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Outline of second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Second-language acquisition classroom research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-language_acquisition_classroom_research"},{"title":"Communication strategies in second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_strategies_in_second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Skill-based theories of second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skill-based_theories_of_second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Category:Second-language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Second-language_acquisition"},{"title":"Category:Bilingualism and second-language acquisition researchers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bilingualism_and_second-language_acquisition_researchers"},{"title":"Studies in Second Language Acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studies_in_Second_Language_Acquisition"}]

## Second Language Acquisition - Search Results

I've found comprehensive information about second language acquisition. Here's an overview of the key findings:

### Definition

Second-language acquisition (SLA), second-language learning or L2 (language 2) acquisition, is the process of learning a language other than one's native language (L1).(no content)Second-language acquisition refers to what learners do; it does not refer to practices in language teaching, although teaching can affect acquisition.

### Research Perspectives

SLA research spans cognitive, social, and linguistic perspectives: cognitive approaches investigate memory and attention processes, and sociocultural theories emphasize the role of social interaction and immersion.(no content)Individual factors like age, motivation, and personality also influence SLA, as seen in discussions on the critical period hypothesis and learning strategies.

### Major Theories

The main purpose of theories of second-language acquisition (SLA) is to shed light on how people who already know one language learn a second language.(no content)Stephen Krashen suggested that language acquisition is driven solely by comprehensible input, language input that learners can understand. Additionally, new theories such as Michael Long's Interaction Hypothesis, Merrill Swain's Output Hypothesis, and Richard Schmidt's Noticing Hypothesis were introduced.

### Academic Discipline

The academic discipline of second-language acquisition is a sub-discipline of applied linguistics and is also closely related to psychology and education.

Web search results for query: "Grounded theory"

Links: [{"title":"The Discovery of Grounded Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Discovery_of_Grounded_Theory"},{"title":"Grounded theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grounded_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Grounded theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Grounded_theory"},{"title":"Kathy Charmaz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathy_Charmaz"},{"title":"Lois McNay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lois_McNay"},{"title":"Cognitive appraisal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_appraisal_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about grounded theory:

## Definition and Methodology

Grounded theory is a systematic methodology that has been largely applied to qualitative research conducted by social scientists, involving the construction of hypotheses and theories through the collection and analysis of data.(no content)Grounded theory involves the application of inductive reasoning, which contrasts with the hypothetico-deductive model used in traditional scientific research.

## How It Works

A study based on grounded theory is likely to begin with a question, or just with the collection of qualitative data. As researchers review the data collected, ideas or concepts become apparent to the researchers—these "emerge" from the data. The researchers tag those ideas/concepts with codes that succinctly summarize them. As more data are collected and re-reviewed, codes can be grouped into higher-level concepts and then into categories, which become the basis of a hypothesis or a new theory.

## History and Developers

Grounded theory methods were developed by two sociologists, Barney Glaser and Anselm Strauss. While collaborating on research on dying hospital patients, Glaser and Strauss developed the constant comparative method which later became known as the grounded theory method.(no content)Glaser and Strauss described their method in detail in their 1967 book, The Discovery of Grounded Theory.

## Applications

From its beginnings, grounded theory methods have become more prominent in fields as diverse as drama, management, manufacturing, and education.

Grounded theory is a systematic methodology that has been largely applied to qualitative research conducted by social scientists, involving the construction of hypotheses and theories through the collection and analysis of data.(no content)Grounded theory involves the application of inductive reasoning, which contrasts with the hypothetico-deductive model used in traditional scientific research.

## How It Works

A study based on grounded theory is likely to begin with a question, or just with the collection of qualitative data. As researchers review the data collected, ideas or concepts become apparent to the researchers—these "emerge" from the data. The researchers tag those ideas/concepts with codes that succinctly summarize them. As more data are collected and re-reviewed, codes can be grouped into higher-level concepts and then into categories, which become the basis of a hypothesis or a new theory.

## History and Developers

Grounded theory methods were developed by two sociologists, Barney Glaser and Anselm Strauss. While collaborating on research on dying hospital patients, Glaser and Strauss developed the constant comparative method which later became known as the grounded theory method.(no content)Glaser and Strauss described their method in detail in their 1967 book, The Discovery of Grounded Theory.

## Applications

From its beginnings, grounded theory methods have become more prominent in fields as diverse as drama, management, manufacturing, and education.

Web search results for query: "Systematic review"

Links: [{"title":"Systematic review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_review"},{"title":"Systematic Reviews (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_Reviews_(journal)"},{"title":"Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preferred_Reporting_Items_for_Systematic_Reviews_and_Meta-Analyses"},{"title":"Category:Systematic review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systematic_review"},{"title":"Umbrella review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umbrella_review"},{"title":"Rapid reviews - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_reviews"},{"title":"GRADE approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GRADE_approach"},{"title":"Cass Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cass_Review"},{"title":"WALANT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WALANT"}]

Here are the search results for "Systematic review":

## Definition

A systematic review is a scholarly synthesis of the evidence on a clearly presented topic using critical methods to identify, define and assess research on the topic.

## Key Characteristics

A systematic review uses a rigorous and transparent approach for research synthesis, with the aim of assessing and, where possible, minimizing bias in the findings.(no content)A systematic review may examine clinical tests, public health interventions, environmental interventions, social interventions, adverse effects, qualitative evidence syntheses, methodological reviews, policy reviews, and economic evaluations.

## Relationship to Meta-Analysis

Systematic reviews are closely related to meta-analyses, and often the same instance will combine both. The distinction between the two is that a meta-analysis uses statistical methods to induce a single number from the pooled data set (such as an effect size), whereas the strict definition of a systematic review excludes that step.

## Reporting Standards

The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement suggests a standardized way to ensure a transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews.(no content)Approximately 174 journals in the health sciences endorse the PRISMA Statement for the reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analysis published in their collections.

## Variations

There are over 30 types of systematic review. Additionally, an umbrella review is a review of systematic reviews or meta-analyses, and compared to a systematic review of literature, in a rapid review, several design decisions and practical steps are undertaken to reduce the time it takes to identify, aggregate and answer the question of interest.

Links: [{"title":"Social presence theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_presence_theory"},{"title":"Social information processing (theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_information_processing_(theory)"},{"title":"Social translucence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_translucence"},{"title":"Social facilitation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_facilitation"},{"title":"Social system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_systems"},{"title":"Social information architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Information_Architecture"},{"title":"Online presence management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_management_system"},{"title":"Presence (telepresence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presence_(telepresence)"},{"title":"Social affordance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_affordance"},{"title":"Social framework analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_framework_analysis"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Social Presence Framework:

## Overview

Social presence theory explores how the "sense of being with another" is influenced by digital interfaces in human-computer interactions.(no content)Developed from the foundations of interpersonal communication and symbolic interactionism, social presence theory was first formally introduced by John Short, Ederyn Williams, and Bruce Christie in The Social Psychology of Telecommunications.

## Definition

Social Presence in recent years has been defined as the feeling of community a learner experiences in an online environment.(no content)Social presence is measured by the ability to project physical and emotional presence and experience it from others in interactions.

## Key Concept

The theory notes that computer-based communication is lower in social presence than face-to-face communication, but different computer-based communications can affect the levels of social presence between communicators and receivers.(no content)Social Presence Theory classifies different communication media on a one-dimensional continuum of social presence, where the degree of social presence is equated to the degree of awareness of the other person in a communication interaction.

## Dimensions

In 2000–2001, Tu argued that within distance learning, social presence rests upon three dimensions: social context, online communication, and interactivity.

The framework has become particularly relevant in the context of online learning and digital communication, helping explain how different media and technologies affect our sense of connection with others.

Links: [{"title":"Language education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_education"},{"title":"Language learning strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_learning_strategies"},{"title":"Mobile-assisted language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile-assisted_language_learning"},{"title":"Glossary of language education terms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_language_education_terms"},{"title":"Language-learning aptitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language-learning_aptitude"},{"title":"Heritage language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heritage_language_learning"},{"title":"Statistical learning in language acquisition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_learning_in_language_acquisition"},{"title":"List of common misconceptions about language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_common_misconceptions_about_language_learning"},{"title":"Tandem language learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tandem_language_learning"},{"title":"How to Learn Any Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_to_Learn_Any_Language"}]

I've completed the web search for "Language learning." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Language education refers to the processes and practices of teaching a second or foreign language.(no content)There are four main learning categories for language education: communicative competencies, proficiencies, cross-cultural experiences, and multiple literacies.

## Key Areas of Language Learning

**Learning Strategies:** Language learning strategies is a term referring to the actions that are consciously deployed by language learners to help them learn or use a language more effectively.

**Language Learning Aptitude:** Language learning aptitude refers to the "prediction of how well, relative to other individuals, an individual can learn a foreign language in a given amount of time and under given conditions".

**Mobile-Assisted Learning:** Mobile-assisted language learning (MALL) is language learning that is assisted or enhanced through the use of a handheld mobile device.

## Common Misconceptions

Research has debunked several myths about language learning:

- While it is often assumed that young children learn languages more easily than adolescents and adults, the reverse is true; older learners are faster.

- General intelligence is actually often a poor indicator of language-learning ability. Motivation, tolerance for ambiguity, and self-esteem are all better indicators of language-learning success.

## Current Global Need

Increasing globalization has created a great need for people in the workforce who can communicate in multiple languages.

I've completed the web search for "Language learning." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Language education refers to the processes and practices of teaching a second or foreign language.(no content)There are four main learning categories for language education: communicative competencies, proficiencies, cross-cultural experiences, and multiple literacies.

## Key Areas of Language Learning

**Learning Strategies:** Language learning strategies is a term referring to the actions that are consciously deployed by language learners to help them learn or use a language more effectively.

**Language Learning Aptitude:** Language learning aptitude refers to the "prediction of how well, relative to other individuals, an individual can learn a foreign language in a given amount of time and under given conditions".

**Mobile-Assisted Learning:** Mobile-assisted language learning (MALL) is language learning that is assisted or enhanced through the use of a handheld mobile device.

## Common Misconceptions

Research has debunked several myths about language learning:

- While it is often assumed that young children learn languages more easily than adolescents and adults, the reverse is true; older learners are faster.

- General intelligence is actually often a poor indicator of language-learning ability. Motivation, tolerance for ambiguity, and self-esteem are all better indicators of language-learning success.

## Current Global Need

Increasing globalization has created a great need for people in the workforce who can communicate in multiple languages.

## Search Results for "Chatbot"

Here's what I found about chatbots:

### Definition and Overview

A chatbot (originally chatterbot) is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

### Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)Many banks, insurers, media companies, e-commerce companies, airlines, hotel chains, retailers, health care providers, government entities, and restaurant chains have used chatbots to answer simple questions, increase customer engagement, for promotion, and to offer additional ways to order from them.

### Modern Chatbots

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, and the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.(no content)Modern chatbots like ChatGPT are often based on large language models called generative pre-trained transformers (GPT). They are based on a deep learning architecture called the transformer, which contains artificial neural networks.

### Notable Chatbots

Some prominent modern chatbots include:
- Gemini (formerly known as Bard) is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot and virtual assistant developed by Google, launched on March 21, 2023 in response to the rise of OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- Grok is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot developed by xAI, launched in November 2023 by Elon Musk.
- DeepSeek is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot by the Chinese company DeepSeek. Released on 20 January 2025, DeepSeek-R1 surpassed ChatGPT as the most downloaded freeware app on the iOS App Store in the United States by 27 January.

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper is a systematic review of chatbot-supported language learning, examining existing research rather than proposing new methods.

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

1. **Chatbot** (tool, uses) - The central technology examined in this systematic review
2. **Language education** (task, uses) - The primary application domain
3. **Natural language processing** (concept, uses) - Enables chatbots to understand and generate conversations
4. **Second-language acquisition** (task, uses) - One of three language learning types reviewed
5. **Systematic review** (method, uses) - Core research methodology employed
6. **Grounded theory** (method, uses) - Used to identify affordances from studies
7. **Social presence theory** (concept, uses) - Framework for analyzing social affordances

All triples have been validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and appropriate entity classifications.

Sources:
- [Chatbot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot)
- [Language education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_education)
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
- [Second-language acquisition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-language_acquisition)
- [Systematic review](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_review)
- [Grounded theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grounded_theory)
- [Social presence theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_presence_theory)
